If food stamp recipients are buying garbage because it's all they can afford, the system is not working. If recipients can't or won't purchase healthy food, then establish food distribution centers for people who need assistance. No sodas, no processed food, no chips, no sugary foods, no empty calorie products--just nutritious food to be served in portions that are sensible. Dieticians should be on the scene to discuss how relatively low cost food that's healthy can be substituted for the swill that's causing an obesity epidemic that will bankrupt this country.

Sorry to some of you libertarian commentators, but as long as public money is at stake, those of us footing the bill have a say in how our tax dollars are spent. I'm in disagreement with Mayor Bloomberg on virtually everything except his bold stand to improve the efficiency of our food stamp program while also trying to tackle the staggering obesity challenge that the US can ill afford.

Dear ekeizer4n ----
Now that you have criticized what is wrong with our thinking -- can you provide insight as to some solutions for the 21st century? What kinds of jobs would you fashion for the future? It is easy to criticize and offer no solutions. How about some answers?

I must add that this might not be the best solution -- but at least someone looks like they are trying to come up with a solution. Besides which, it is good to teach girls how to use male oriented equipment....some day that may give them the problem solving skills to fix the plumbing in their own house. As an only child, my father taught me as many skills as did my mother. I rarely had to look to anyone to repair things around my house. I had the problem solving skills and the right tools to do it myself. Not a bad idea when money is low and other bills need to be paid - like food.

What ever happened to "shop" in school? I think we have bigger problems than just girls not having an interest in learning these skills, it's boys too. Part of the problem is every kid is forced toward a college prep path, even if that college education is essentially meaningless (do you really need a college degree to flip burgers?).

It's been a slow, gradual decline that has been going on for many decades. When I was in junior high, I was amazed by all of the great shop equipment provided when the school was built in the 1950s. But by the time I had gotten there a mere 10 years later, much of that equipment sat idle. We didn't get to use it. I fantasized over what it must have been like in the 1950s when kids (boys only, for sure) got to "play" with that stuff.

And factory tours, what are those? There was a time were lots of manufacturers had tours, but they vanished well before the manufacturing vanished. My "favorite" factory tour is Hershey's Chocolate World, an amusement park ride that replaced their actual factory tour: a Disneyesque version of the real world. That's all kids know these days!

By the way, these skills are useful around the house too; you don't have to be a complete doofus when it comes to home repair.

“Girls don’t naturally gravitate toward engineering....”

--I can't imagine why that is the case. Could it be that they are given little-to-no encouragement at every stage?

“Not letting your children learn the hands-on component of the theory of science is killing us as a nation,” Ms. Sharris said. “You have to stop giving kids books and start giving them tools.”

--I agree with the other readers. The two are not mutually exclusive. Hands-on skills are critical, but so are analytical skills. Judging from the photograph, I'd hate the idea of the brown-skinned kids getting the tools, while others get the book and the education for the "knowledge" industries. Way to stratify society.

--I also was surprised by the comment of the board member who said that manufacturing was not dirty work. My understanding is that it can be dirty, and it also is extremely repetitive, sometimes dangerous work. The chief reason to do it, apart from the lack of opportunity, were the benefits and the job security. Those are gone now.

I spent a lot of years in graduate school gaining a PhD in biochemistry. Intellect, quick thinking and theoretical problem solving were highly valued attributes but there was also a divide between the "tinkerer's" and the others and that is easily traced to whether or not an individual had ever used a wrench, drill or screw driver when they were younger.
In high school I took all the college prep courses but my after-school job was at a service station pumping gas, changing oil and patching tires. This translated later into the guy willing to replumb the HPLC, tear apart the vacuum pump or keep all the computers operating. Today I work for a software company in the chemical information business - this isn't where I thought I was going 20 years ago.
The point is one summer camp exposing these kids to manufacturing environments and technologies doesn't pigeon-hole them into a dead-end career. Rather it expands their horizons and opens their minds to other possibilities. At least one 17 year old knows, and another 15 year old learned, that it takes practice, practice and more practice to translate what you're thinking through your hands and into something real.
Whatever becomes of the American job market, people who can think with their minds, work with their hands and explain themselves to everyone else will find their way. Current public education doesn't seem to focus on any of those three things so let's have more summer camps teaching drill press technique, wire stripping and soldering.

Nautika is right: Manufacturing IS cool. Local, micro manufacturing may be a small thing now, but it's growing and the effects will soon be felt. The efficiencies in store are too great to be ignored. Putting to the side all the wonderful skills of general application a camp like this teaches, these girls are laying the groundwork for competitive advantage in this future job space. They may or may not elect to pursue it. They may want to be a surgeon, or an engineer, or an artist. The choice will be theirs, and they will have developed the analytical tools to negotiate whatever path they choose. Win-Win.

Focusing on her curiosity/interest in Art/Design/Architecture & Photography, I designed a very special 2-week multi-experiential Program, involving Jewelery Fabrication,Glassblowing,Photography,Architecture & many more hands on experiences-
take a look...
http://flic.kr/s/aHsjvo4QU6
The point is - unless more kids are allowed to MAKE things-
take them apart- (and hopefully reassemble them in a different fashion) and LEARN with their hands as well as their brains- we will, as a society- be poised to fail- because TRUE innovation & creative "bursts" don't always come from sitting in front of a LCD monitor-

Great Article.

You go, girls!  Oh, how I wish opportunities like this had been available when I was a teen.  I really wanted to learn woodworking, but that was something only offered to the "slow" kids and even then only to the boys.  The only crafts my school considered suitable for girls were home economics and typing.  I've taught myself much since then, but could have learned more if it had been offered.  And now that I've gushed over practical knowledge, I'm going to go pick up my reserve books from the library.  And a very good weekend to you, too!
I'm consumed with envy.  I date to when girls were forbidden to take shop in high school.

My husband and I have a great handyman who comes and does all the stuff we never learned how to do...he makes a VERY nice living from all the folks like us. I so wish I had had the opportunity to go to a camp like this.  Do they have one for grownups?

One has to be able to read and even enjoy reading, to be able to do math, science and the skills it takes to run a drill press or design some type of improvement for an existing piece if machinery. Am SO glad the article noted once again that skilled workers are needed and in short supply here in the states.

When will public schools start pushing the classes we had in the 50's and 60's like shop, auto, wood working, mechanics etc? These provided a skilled populace that gave us the workmen/women we needed in industry.

Then came the 70's and a glut of political science majors who wanted to go into law and government, the two areas that have NOT served us as a nation.

This is price gouging pure & simple. This should be ilegal, but the pharmaceutical lobby is very powerful. Obama's plans for national health care will fold if he can't keep pharmaceutical companies from robing consumers blind.

I once worked in a large drug company in ,say, one side of the Atlantic. I was shocked to read their mission statement one day, on their intranet page. It read - "The objective of the company was to give continuous returns and value to the shareholders and investors" , instead of saying, discovering more useful drugs and making them affordable to all people. That day itself, I lost my respect for big drug companies. If companies have such objectives along with all the market-inherent supply manipulations why will the drugs be available all the time. We cannot trust the drug makers anymore. It is a pity that even basic drugs without insurance cost a ton at the drug store. That is heights of foolishness at the heights of civilization advancement.

Thanks to the Times for highlighting this issue. As a pediatric hospitalist, a physician specializing in the care of hospitalized children, drug (and vaccine shortages) have been an issue for years. It seems to be getting worse now. Regularly our pharmacy puts out reports about what medications are in short supply and need to be conserved, and which medicines are completely unavailable and require substitution. Regardless of how one feels about healthcare reform, market solutions, and federal intervention, no one can claim that our supply system is working as well as it should.
This is a problem that requires rational discussion and bipartisan collaboration. Let's not pull another FAA shutdown or debt ceiling/default threat. Let's create a system that works. We're all in this together, no one is immune from these potential shortages.
The public needs to be as well informed of this as it is about medications for erectile dysfunction and short eyelashes, which curiously have not had their supply lines impacted.

Heather Bresch put her finger on the two main problems: lack of money for FDA inspections and lack of big enough profits for giant drug conglomerates, which also severely limit licensing for generic versions of patented drugs. In high school civics we learned that when private enterprise cannot or will not produce what's needed, the government can and should step in to do what private enterprise won't or can't for the common good. If ever the drug companies spend as much on research as they  spend on advertising and promotion, I could be sympathetic. For now, they don't deserve it.

And this friends and neighbors is the free market in health care.

Since drug companies do not make their obscene profits on these life sustaining drugs they see no need in making them at all.After all, it really is ALL about profit.

Now if say Mrs Koch, if there is a Mrs Koch, gets ovarian cancer and cannot get the drug to cure her, we may see a shift towards availability again. But then if price is no object to Mrs Koch, she will pay the exorbitant price of 20 times the going charge. I guess Mrs John Que will just have to die. But for the GOP, who said national health care is death panels and socialistic, they should not have a problem. Free markets rule.

Well if you live in LI and pay $15 to cross the GWB then you are 1) quoting the 2014 cash rate, not todays rate. 2) living in LI and somehow owning a car but not an EZ Pass! A strange circumstance.

What your statistic does not tell me is how much it costs to maintain and provide on site emergency coverage the 2 miles or so and 14 tracks of GWB. It is considerably more than to maintain 14 miles of tarmac thrown down on the dirt (especially to the standards often seen on the US Interstate system).

So, it is $8.50 (2 gallons of gas) vs the 70c/gallon of gas tax $1.40 of tax in $8.50 of gas. 6 times more expensive to maintain roadway on a bridge than on tarmac. Sounds reasonable to me.

Remember PANYNJ allows you to sign up for HOV pricing on their river crossings. Put 3 people in your car and it is only a $3 crossing.

I love statistics to put things in perspective. After I pay the 15 dollars to cross the river, the next 15 dollars worth of gas will take me 148 miles away from NYC.
That is to the city of Albany, 151 miles away. Remarkable, huh?

Why do people stay in abusive relationships? Their are millions of men who would never physocally or emotionally abuse their partners but for some reason some women will stay with the abuser. I will never understand this behavior. If someone hits me the relationship is over!

It's stunning to me that in all but one of the comments, including the seriously disturbing ones by Mark Klein and the person who rationalized the murder as cultural difference, there is almost no mention of the racist aspect of it. Not only should Mr. Parvaiz not have abused his wife, let alone contracted to have his wife murdered, but then to blame it on others, including using the racist cover that "three black men" did it, is sickening to no end. We need an end to misogyny, an end to sexism, an end to abuse of women, an end to racism, and this man needs to go behind bars for the rest of his life.

I don't believe in arranged marriage;the parties don't know each other, nor take the time to know each other. I am sorry about her murder, but, there should have been a better solution to the husband wanting out of the marriage. Also, why didn't the brother who receive the text message from the murdered woman tell the police?

#20 - More like a "dishonor" killing.

Sad to say, I called this one the first time I saw the story. My husband said I watch too much "Crime and Investigation" network but my radar is up.

I also wonder why her family didn't intervene when she sent her brother the text. I guess it's cultural and not much to do with NJ divorce courts, which wouldn't have heard their divorce anyway.

They should never have gotten married in the first place. The reasons he gives for her murder are so childish. I feel sorry for the two kids. Their life has been ruined. Congratulations to the police. Good work.

Most writers seem to ignore the fact that the actual shooter was a woman, though the other plotter. So this wasn't a typical Islamic honor killing. There was no honor in this killing, just a plot by two adulterers to get rid of the woman the guy was married to. There was no honor in this murder; not only first degree murder, but done in the presence of the child of the target and her "husband".

What is curious and surprising was the Pakistani-Indian cooperation in this dire effort. Surprising given all the chronic animosity between the Pakistanis and the Indians. Finally, I think Dr. Klein's comment blaming this tragedy on unfair divorce laws for men is absurd. Dr. Klein should be ashamed of himself for effectively justifying this based on what appears to be his own personal experience with divorce.

Please let us not fool ourselves with some of the value-dependent comments. This is absolutely, a crime against humanity and a senseless and tragic option of solving family issues and it had nothing to do with race, religion and cultural background. There are over 7 million incidents of domestic violence in the U.S. and it cuts across boundaries and identities.
let us not undermine the tragic loss of this poor woman and the tender child left with a traumatic legacy. This should serve to a teaching moment for all of us and wackos should not hijack the discussion/opportunity!!!
